pathogens.name: Rabies Virus
pathogens.definition: A fatal viral encephalitis transmitted through the saliva of infected animals, primarily through bites. Rabies is almost always fatal once clinical symptoms appear, but is preventable through post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP).
pathogens.transmissionMode: Zoonotic (animal bite, scratch, or mucous membrane exposure to infected saliva)
pathogens.infectiousPeriod: Animals: 3-7 days before symptom onset until death; Humans: Not transmitted person-to-person
pathogens.clinicalPresentation: Prodrome (fever, headache, malaise) → Acute neurologic phase (anxiety, confusion, agitation, hallucinations, hydrophobia, aerophobia) → Coma → Death
pathogens.diagnosticTests: Direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) test on brain tissue, RT-PCR, serology (antibody detection in CSF/serum)
pathogens.ppe: Standard PPE for healthcare workers; Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for exposed individuals
pathogens.controlMeasures: Immediate wound washing, post-exposure prophylaxis (rabies immunoglobulin + vaccine series), animal control, pre-exposure vaccination for high-risk individuals

pathogens.name: Mpox (Monkeypox)
pathogens.definition: A zoonotic viral disease caused by the monkeypox virus, related to smallpox but generally less severe. Characterized by fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy.
pathogens.transmissionMode: Zoonotic (animal-to-human), close contact with infected person (respiratory droplets, skin lesions, contaminated materials), sexual contact
pathogens.infectiousPeriod: From symptom onset until all lesions have crusted over and healed
pathogens.clinicalPresentation: Fever, headache, muscle aches, lymphadenopathy → Rash (macules → papules → vesicles → pustules → scabs) starting on face and spreading to body
pathogens.isolationPrecautions: Contact + Airborne Precautions (until all lesions crusted)
pathogens.ppe: N95 respirator, gown, gloves, eye protection
pathogens.controlMeasures: Isolation of cases, contact tracing, vaccination (smallpox vaccine provides cross-protection), environmental cleaning
pathogens.outbreakRisk: Moderate (2022 global outbreak demonstrated sustained human-to-human transmission)

pathogens.name: Poliovirus
pathogens.definition: A highly infectious viral disease that primarily affects young children and can cause irreversible paralysis. Polio has been eradicated in most countries through vaccination but remains endemic in some regions.
pathogens.infectiousPeriod: 7-10 days before symptom onset to 3-6 weeks after
pathogens.clinicalPresentation: Most infections asymptomatic; Minor illness (fever, fatigue, headache, vomiting); Nonparalytic (aseptic meningitis); Paralytic polio (acute flaccid paralysis)
pathogens.diagnosticTests: Viral culture from stool, throat swab, CSF; PCR; Serology
pathogens.controlMeasures: Vaccination (OPV or IPV), isolation of cases, contact tracing, environmental surveillance (wastewater testing), hand hygiene, safe water/sanitation
pathogens.outbreakRisk: High in unvaccinated populations; Vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV) outbreaks possible
